Beyblade is mostly preparation. testing, customizing, match-ups etc.
OP parts can sometimes be hard countered with specific combinations.
Too add more "strategy" you use a "deck" of Beyblades.
You pick and choose based on what you think your opponent will use.
You can only have 1 copy of a part in your deck.
The only technically skill is launching.

The atk/sta/def thing is just a simplification of "spin longer or get a knockout"
It's easier to explain and understand. Most play with Beyblade casually.

com:
Hey /toy/,
New collector here, so far I've put together a small cabinet of McFarlane DC, Marvel Legends and NECA Horror figures, with a few other series dotted about (I'm a sucker for anything Toxic Crusaders), but when looking at other lines to start, I need some advice.

I usually start off with the 'main' characters (founding Avengers, The Trinity etc) but with other lines like Retro Star Wars, G.I. Joe, especially Transformers and Power Rangers Lightning Collection and some others I've looked at, this seems to be increasingly difficult to source. Once a Wave is released and sold out, am I stuck to scouring eBay and the like? Or are Waves sometimes re-released?

I'm in the U.K. which makes it a bit harder, but even when sucking it up and looking at doing a big BBTS order, there's some stuff I just can't mind (Lightning MMPR Blue, for example)
Struggling to decide which lines to persue so that I'm not stuck with grabbing JUST C-List characters (as much as I do love ML Maggot).

Thanks for any advice

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10171699
Go on Facebook and join various local/UK toy groups. See if there's any dedicated to selling/buying the line of your choice. And go from there. In time, you may notice some regular trusted sellers.

Also go with Amazon and the like. I assume there's an Amazon UK?

As for what lines, it really depends on what you like. I presume you're a 6" to 7" collector. The lines you've mentioned are pretty much the best non-Eastern on the market for that kind of stuff.

GI Joe are probably the most advance engineering-wise and bang for your buck-wise (unless they're ludicrously overpriced in the UK?).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10171699
You're going to end up buying things that won't matter to you as soon as you take them out of the box. Whether they're your favorites or you fill a mighty rare need, it's totally normal and something you figure out for yourself anyway. Only when you "play" with them while you buy more toys, the sentimental value will be much more clear

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10171699
If you're looking for UK stores, other than ebay I'd recommend StarActionFigures, ComicsandCocktails and uhhh...Kapow. Though I can't 100% recommend Kapow since I've never personally used them.
The other two are great though. C&C especially since they have free shipping!

>Zoomers understand that to an extent (I rarely see zoomers having an expensive hobby like collecting.) Its mostly millennials and gen xers that are living pay check to pay check.
that's because zoomers dont have money. They can't buy shit, thus need to be more selective, so it only looks like they're more careful with their money.

Once they have money, they'll be spending it like nuts and soon be overspending money they dont have. The mentality is "i can pay all my bills this one week and still ahvea boatload of money that will buy me more shit the rest of the month" and soon it becomes "i can pay all my bills this one week, and then use my credit card to buy a boatload of shit which i can easily pay off by the end of the year with my yearly bonus, tax return, and reselling the toys on /toy/'s BST thread"

It's akin to how the model train collecting was seen as a Silent Generation thing, but then became a Boomer thing, and now generation xers have started taking it up because they can now afford those extremely overpriced models and set ups.
See also audiophiles, where people thought only boomers who could afford expensive audio equipment could be fooled into buying the latest new snake oil that made the old snake oil look like normal oil. People thought that the next generation (once they had higher paying jobs) wouldn't be like the old generation because the internet would inform everyone what's real or not. But now everyone (with money) is buying and updating every year, because there's a hundred times more shilling going on.

In short, if you keep working in that nursing home, you're eventually going to see the same shit happening with X, Y, and Z.... if things don't collapse in the next decades to come. Shit isn't as rosy as it once was, which you missed out on in the 80s, 90s, and early 00s, and made boomers think everything would work out fine until they became broke.

com:
Welcome back everyone, hope you're all doing well.

The time has come for us to finally have new releases in the line! By now most of everyone who ordered Olivier and Vania should have them in hand. Its seems the delay was worth it as Olivier seems to be one of the better releases in the line. Vania also seems to be a generally good release as people are having fun messing with her and Olivier. As of now, we only have one other figure up for Pre-Order right now, that being Bikini Clover. Currently we know that the Polynian and Touhou series will continue since Marisa is supposedly the next in line to go up. The official Poly 4Koma is still going and it seems its been well received as it gives little look into the everyday lives of the Polys we know. We also had a wonderful surprise in the form of the new Polynian MLL body! We finally have a counterpart to the Iana body. Aside from that things have been pretty quiet for the time being.

As always, here is the assistance e-mail for those who need it, so if any problem should arise, feel free to contact them over at "user_support@mile-stone.jp" or the shop you purchased the figure from.

Once again, feel free to share your photos and adventures, they add life and some fun to the thread. Also, welcome newcomers, we hope you enjoy your stay.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: This is a bait thread made by an ignorant retard wanting to start a brand war, but just look at 3p Transformers. The issue is experience, knowledge and reliable factories, not some magical access to one specific factory that Bandai or Hasbro or whatever uses. com: Hi /toy/, tourist from /tg/ here with a question. I'm trying to strip the paint from the Schleich warthog pictured. I tried immersing it in isopropyl alcohol and scrubbing with a toothbrush, which would normally work perfectly on removing acrylic paint from games workshop minis and such. However, warty here is completly unaffected, even after overnight immersion and a rub down with a heavy duty scrubbing brush. Curiously, the alcohol worked perfectly on the Scorpion (same manufacturer). Can /toy/ offer any guidance to a fa/tg/uy?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10173840
Don't use acetone. Never use acetone on plastic. Never ever.

You never know what will work like a charm and what will instantly melt your figure. It's not worth the risk.

Soak them in a degreaser like Simple Green or Purple Power or some diluted lye, then scrub them with a toothbrush and it will all flake off.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: One more vote for trying a 24-hour soak in Simple Green

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10173957
Simple Green works wonders for unvarnished tabletop miniatures, I give it my full endorsement. I'm not sure how toy paint differs, I imagine it has a rubber inclusion that will require a soak for longer than 24 hours, but it will not harm the plastic.

last_replies.com:

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
how large is your collection that you need a checklist?
I have literally thousands and i remember basically every purchase I've made. With the few that i can't remember, i sure as hell remember when browsing at a convention or through ebay, so i'm reminded when combing through their shelves/pegs/listings that i don't need X.

The only thing i don't remember is when dealing with doubles/triples/quadtruples/etc. So i know i have multiples of certain army builders, but not their exact number. Still, if i find a cheap army builder, it doesn't hurt ot buy another.

Is this a problem people who DON'T play with their toys, where you just keep them in mint in their box?

I know i have a problem with books, comics, games, and movies where i buy up a bunch of shit so i can read/watch/play them in the future, and tend to forget i even own issues 150-158 of The Maxx vs Hulk series or whatever. Or how i avoid buying anymore Simpsons boxsets because i can't remember if i own anything after season 10. Or if i even own the Silent Hill HD collection for PS3.
I don't remember if i own any of htat shit because i never touched them years after buying them. Whereas everything i have watched/read/played with, i know exactly who i have, even if i haven't touched them in over 20 years, like my ARAH vintage GI Joes. I even remember which accessories go with whom, even though i mixed them up in a box with hundreds of other accessories decades ago.
